data.title: BASICS; Safe Online at Home: Keeping Out Uninvited Guests
data.meta_description: Firewalls that keep uninvited guests from invading computers come in two varieties: software and hardware; drawing (M)
data.text:
BECAUSE so much of my work finds me online for hours a day, deciding to switch from a pokey dial-up modem to always-on broadband was a no-brainer. D.S.L. was available in my Manhattan neighborhood, so I ignored the many D.S.L. service nightmares that friends had warned me about and signed up.

What nobody warned me about -- not my friends and, more disturbingly, not my Internet service provider -- was the scary stuff that happened after I was connected. At the end of my first day in the fast lane, I was shutting down my PC when a Windows prompt warned me that by doing so I would disconnect a user called Dr. Stealth from my computer. Was I sure I wanted to shut down?

I gasped. I blinked. I hit the power switch.

Dr. Stealth? My computer was telling me that it had been hacked. Or if not actually hacked -- in the malicious sense usually associated with the term -- it had at the very least been electronically invaded by a total stranger whose motive I could only guess at during the hours I lay awake that night. Without realizing it, I had left my computer open to uninvited visitors.

What I needed, several fellow fast-trackers told me, was a firewall. For any business that is connected to the Net, a firewall is a given. For most home users tapping into the Net with a fast cable modem or D.S.L. connection, however, firewalls are a foreign language.

To some extent, every computer hooked to the Internet on any kind of connection needs a firewall.

Every computer that connects to the Net has or is assigned a unique identifier called an Internet Protocol, or I.P., address, which acts as a kind of home address for sending and receiving information, and hackers use communications programs that scan the Net for I.P. addresses. The hackers are looking for computers with open ports -- entry points used by programs to communicate with the Internet -- that are vulnerable to attack.

Broadband users are more vulnerable to attacks because their ''always on'' connections mean that their computers are out there as potential targets for many more hours a day.
